title: Amazon FBA Product Launch: 5 Things to Check Before You Bet Your Money
content:
Every year, thousands of Amazon sellers lose money not because they worked hard — but because they launched the wrong product. They had the data. They had Helium10. They had JungleScout. They did everything "by the book."

And they still failed.

Here's the uncomfortable truth: data tools tell you what's happening. They don't tell you whether you should launch.

After a decade running product launches across consumer electronics, accessories, and outdoor gear categories, I've developed a 5-point checklist that separates products worth betting on from those that will quietly drain your capital.

Why Helium10 and JungleScout Aren't Enough

Don't get me wrong — Helium10 and JungleScout are excellent tools. They show you search volume, estimated revenue, keyword difficulty, and competitor metrics. For data collection, they're industry standard.

But here's the gap: they aggregate the past. They don't synthesize judgment about your specific situation.

Seeing that "insulated water bottle" gets 150,000 monthly searches tells you demand exists. It doesn't tell you:

  • Whether a new entrant at your price point can realistically capture 1-3% market share
  • Whether your specific COGS leaves enough margin after FBA fees and PPC
  • Whether bad reviews in the category reveal a differentiation gap you can exploit
  • Whether the IP landscape will get you suspended in 90 days

Those are judgment calls. And that's where most sellers either over-rely on gut instinct or, worse, skip them entirely because they don't know what to look for.

Here are the 5 things you need to check before you wire money to a supplier.

1. Market Demand — Is It Real, Consistent, and Growing?

High search volume is necessary but not sufficient. You need to dig deeper:

  • Trend direction: Is demand growing, flat, or declining? A 150,000 monthly search volume that's been shrinking 20% year-over-year is a trap.
  • Seasonality: Is this a year-round product or a 3-month spike? Camping gear that peaks in May-July requires different inventory strategy than evergreen household items.
  • Organic vs. PPC-driven demand: Check if top sellers are ranking organically or burning budget on ads to maintain visibility. If 80% of top-10 listings are sponsored, the organic moat is gone — everyone's paying to play.
  • Review velocity: Categories with 50+ reviews/month per top product indicate sustained purchase activity, not just initial hype.

Red flag: Search volume above 100,000 but fewer than 3 products with 1,000+ reviews = category is newer/riskier than it appears.

2. Competition — Can You Realistically Grab 1-3% Share?

This is where most sellers make their biggest mistake. They see high revenue numbers from top competitors and assume the pie is big enough for everyone.

What they miss:

  • Brand concentration: If 3 brands control 60%+ of category revenue, you're not entering a market — you're trying to chip away at a fortress.
  • Review wall: Top products with 10,000-50,000 reviews took years to accumulate. You can't buy your way to that trust quickly. If you launch into this environment, expect to lose money for 12-18 months building review equity.
  • PPC cost reality: Check average CPC for your target keywords. If top keywords cost $2.50-4.00 per click with 4-6% conversion, your customer acquisition cost could be $40-100 for a $25 product. That's not a business — that's a charity.
  • New entrant success rate: Look at products launched in the last 12 months. How many reached 100+ reviews? If fewer than 20% did, the category is hostile to new entrants.

The honest question: "Why would an Amazon customer choose my product over the established players?" If your answer is "it's cheaper" or "similar quality," that's not a strategy — that's a race to the bottom.

3. Margin Viability — Does the Math Actually Work?

This is non-negotiable. You need 25%+ net margin after all costs to build a sustainable business. Most sellers calculate this incorrectly because they forget items.

Full cost structure check:

  • COGS (product + packaging + quality inspection + shipping to Amazon)
  • FBA fees (referral fee 8-15% + fulfillment fee by size/weight)
  • PPC budget (conservatively 15-25% of revenue in competitive categories)
  • Returns and refunds (budget 3-8% depending on category)
  • Storage fees (especially Q4 long-term storage if you over-order)
  • Platform fees and currency conversion

Example reality check: A $30 product with $8 COGS sounds like 73% gross margin. After FBA fees ($5), PPC ($6), returns ($1.50), and overhead ($1.50), you net $8 — barely 26%. And that's before you account for initial launch spending to build velocity.

If the math doesn't clearly work on paper, it definitely won't work in execution.

4. Differentiation — What Do Bad Reviews Reveal?

This is the most underutilized research step. Most sellers read top reviews to validate demand. The smarter play is reading the 1-star and 2-star reviews to find the product gap.

What you're looking for:

  • Recurring complaints: If 30%+ of negative reviews mention the same issue (leaking, durability, misleading sizing, difficult assembly), that's a real gap.
  • Price-to-expectation mismatch: Customers complaining that a $20 product feels cheap signals room for a better-quality option at $28-32.
  • Missing features customers want: "I wish it came with a carrying case" or "would be perfect if it had a warranty" — these are free product improvement briefs.

The differentiation question isn't "is my product slightly better?" It's: "Is my improvement significant enough that customers will choose me over established competitors with 10x more reviews?"

A 15% quality improvement is not enough. A solved pain point that 35% of buyers complain about? That's a wedge.

5. Launch Risk — What's the Minimum Viable Bet?

Even good products can fail due to launch execution risk. Evaluate:

  • Minimum order quantity: If your supplier requires 1,000 units minimum and you need 3 months to sell through, that's $8,000-15,000 sitting in Amazon warehouses during your validation period. Can you afford to be wrong?
  • IP and trademark risks: Do any top competitors have design patents on product features? Brand registry protection? A suspension 60 days into launch can be business-ending.
  • Supplier reliability: First-time suppliers need test orders. Budget for at least one quality control failure before you find a reliable partner.
  • Time to first sale: From purchase order to Amazon warehouse to first organic sale is typically 90-120 days. You need runway for this. If you're cash-constrained, this timeline will break you.
  • Category restrictions: Some categories require Amazon approval. Others have specific compliance requirements (electrical safety, chemical labeling). Research these before committing.

The 5-Point Scorecard

Before any launch decision, run your product through these 5 dimensions and score each 1-10:

  1. Market Demand — Real, growing, not driven by hype
  2. Competition — Room for a new entrant to capture 1-3% share
  3. Margin Viability — 25%+ net after all costs
  4. Differentiation — A specific, solvable gap in existing products
  5. Launch Risk — Acceptable MOQ, no IP landmines, clear timeline

Score below 30/50 total? Don't launch. Score 35+? Worth serious consideration. Score 40+? Execute fast.

The point isn't to find perfect products — it's to make informed bets. Every launch carries risk. The goal is to make sure the risk is worth taking.
